definitions.definition: all the people working on a ship, plane, etc.

examples.text: **crew members**
all the men and women in the crew
None of the passengers and crew were injured.
The crew of the plane instructed everyone to remain seated.
a change of crew in Frankfurt
The crew was/were extremely helpful.

definitions.definition: all the people working on a ship, plane etc. except the officers who are in charge

examples.text: the officers and crew

definitions.definition: a group of people with special skills working together

examples.text: a **film/camera/TV crew**
**a fire/an emergency/a rescue crew**
It took **ambulance crews** more than an hour to free them.
A fire crew was/were called to the scene.
The cast and crew of the movie are giving it their all.
Fire crews were called to the house at around 5 o'clock.
Maintenance crews have been working 18-hours shifts to repair the damage.
The film crew and the actors had all left the studio by then.
Our support crew followed behind in two Land Rovers.
The house was soon besieged by TV crews and photographers.
Two crews of six men carried out the work in shifts.
We have camera crews from ABC, CBS and NBC coming.
a maintenance/​support crew
The people she invited were a pretty **motley crew** *(= a strange mix of types of people)*.
Let's get a crew together and go to the pub.
We found him in the canteen with a crew of assorted computer geeks.

definitions.definition: a team of people who row boats in races

examples.text: a member of the Cambridge crew

definitions.definition: the sport of rowing with other people in a boat

examples.text: I’m thinking of going out for crew this semester *(= joining the  team)*.

definitions.definition: a person or team of people who sail boats in races or for pleasure (usually not including the captain)

wordOrigin: late Middle English: from Old French creue ‘augmentation, increase’, feminine past participle of croistre ‘grow’, from Latin crescere. The original sense was ‘band of soldiers serving as reinforcements’; hence it came to denote any organized armed band or, generally, a company of people (late 16th cent.).
